title-group.article-title: Dynamic reliability of gears in a wind turbine gearbox under the conditions of variable wind speed and small samples

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China

author-notes.corresp: T Chen, School of Mechanical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China. Email: ct810719@163.com

abstract.p: Owing to the characteristics of the variable wind speed and small gear samples, the gear reliability of a wind turbine gearbox is hard to predict. In order to solve this problem, a complete reliability prediction model is presented in this article. Firstly, distribution parameters of the gear stress are deduced according to the variable wind data, and a linear path is defined for the time-varying stress. Next, historical gear samples are transformed into the equivalent prior data by grey relational analysis and then the posterior data is deduced by Bayes data fusion. Then, distribution parameters and a non-linear path are determined for the time-varying gear strength. After that, the dynamic reliability of gears in a wind turbine gearbox is calculated on the basis of the stress–strength interference model and the Monte Carlo sampling. Lastly, an instance is given to verify the validity of this model. The result shows that the variable wind speed will decline the reliability of wind gears, in addition, the reliability declines faster than its expectation in the infant mortality period.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The wind power has become a new kind of green energy which is widely used. It is of great significance to the economy and environment because of its clean source and renewability. In the past decades, the wind power industry has developed rapidly, and such development makes it one kind of the representative new energy. Consequently, the researches regarding the wind power system and relevant components have also been developing continually.

Gears of a wind turbine gearbox are important parts and are significant to the whole system. Its reliability is related to many aspects, such as proper material choice, fabrication techniques and structure interactions (coupled with CFD), etc. Based on the traditional consideration, the gear loads are uncharged in the reliability model. But this simplified hypothesis is not reasonable any more when gears are used in a wind turbine, because the wind velocity is hard to be maintained as the mounting height of the nacelle is about 80–100 m. The disturbed load passes from the blades to the main drive shaft and thence to the gearbox. It is finally reflected in the form of fluctuating gear stress features. Generally speaking, safety factor is the major reference for indicating the gear reliability. It has a clear mathematical expression and is handy for use.1,2 For instance, the gear safety factor can be easily calculated according to the standard ISO-6336. But based on some modern studies regarding gear reliability, the results have broken the deterministic view of tradition. The stress or strength of the gears cannot be considered as constant any more, it is random variable and obeys certain distribution. Compared to the deterministic way, the random theory considers the discretization of stress/strength and it is more practical.3–5 With the development of the theories regarding dynamic reliability in recent years, researches on the dynamic strength/stress degradation have attracted wide interest. Many studies demonstrate that the strength of material is not only discrete but also irreversible. The first degradation model is presented by Gertsbackh and Kordonskiy. They point out that the microstructure of material gradually changes due to the accumulation of fatigue damage. Moreover, it will lead to a degradation of mechanical properties.6 Subsequently, Meeker and Hamada7 pointed out that the degradation failure analysis (GFA) can resolve some complicated problems, which existed in the traditional reliability theories and some engineering applications. Putic et al.8 considers that the distribution of the residual strength can be affected by numbers of the load cycles, and it will degenerate gradually with the increase of the cycle numbers. Gu9 introduces the most common seven strength degradation models in detail. The “double parameters fatigue criterion” indicates that the residual strength is decided by the degree of damage and the current load. Next, the power function model which is proposed by Schaff better describes the strength degradation path of the steel materials.10,11 At the same time, lots of researches show that high cycle fatigue is one of the key reasons leading to failure.12–14

The carrying capacity of wind turbine is often coordinated with the mean wind speed and the turbulence level. So, in most cases, the acquire life of years in a wind turbine is generally no less than 20 years, whether it is applied to off-shore or on-shore. But it is difficult to obtain failure data by the conventional life test or even by the accelerated life test. This situation caused serious limitation for acquisition of failure data, and it will restrict the application of the stress–strength interference model. How to carry out a statistical inference on the condition of small samples is a meaningful topic of classical statistics. The correlative methods are presented: The information of entropy method transforms the component information into the system information; then the prior samples used for the reliability statistic are formed.15,16 In the Bayes method, the prior distribution and likelihood function are used to predict the posterior distribution. This approach of information expansion can evidently decrease the requirement of the numbers of samples.17,18 Fiducial method considers the parameters as random variables whose distribution type mainly depends on the observed samples, then the confidence interval of reliability is deduced. But Fiducial method is not as perfect as classical theory (such as Bayes method), and there are a few limitations.19,20 Besides that, for the purpose of obtaining the prior samples, source data is transformed into the equivalent samples under different conditions, and much work is done. It was developed from the linear fusion to the non-linear fusion and from the single-fusion to the multi-fusion.21 Also, some relevant algorithms of data fusion are presented, such as Kalman filter method, adaptive weighting method, D-S evidence theory, neural network theory, etc.22–25 All these methods provide good basis for reliability researches on the condition of small samples.

This study is focused on the dynamic reliability of gears in a wind turbine gearbox under the conditions of variable wind speed and small samples. The probability distribution and the time-varying path of both gear stress and gear strength are separately deduced. On these bases, a complete stress–strength interference model is presented, and the dynamic reliability of gear in a wind turbine gearbox is calculated by using the Monte Carlo sampling.

sec.title: Dynamic stress–strength interference model
sec.p:
The stress–strength interference model is a basic method for reliability research. The essence of this model is the probability that the gear strength (S) is greater than its stress (s), that is, R = (S–s > 0). In addition, gear strength or gear stress is considered to obey certain distribution. Since the asymptotes of their probability density curves are the same coordinate axis as shown in Figure 1, there must be an overlap between the two curves.26 It is just the possible failure region of the gears, and, the smaller the area means the higher the reliability. So the stress–strength interference model is a valid way for gear reliability analysis. Figure 1.
Dynamic stress–strength interference model.

If the time-varying effect is further considered, a dynamic stress–strength interference model can be formed as shown in Figure 1.27 Both of the strength and the stress are random variables in this dynamic model, in addition, shape of each overlap region is different owing to the time-varying gear strength and gear stress.

The cyclic loading will lead to the aging of material and the degeneration of gear strength. It mainly depends on the internal structure of material and has the feature of irreversibility. Now there are dozens of strength degradation models, and the power function model is the one which is widely applied.28 The expression is as follows (1)fS(t)=β0tβ1

where β0 is the degradation rate of strength, it is related to the working conditions; β1 is the shape parameter, it is only related to the material. When the material is given, β1 can be considered as constant.

Meanwhile, differing from gear strength, the stress of loaded gear will deteriorate gradually owing to the wear and pitting. So, gear stress displays a different path with gear strength due to their dissimilar mechanisms. Gear stress mainly depends on the external factors such as tooth profile, working condition, etc. It satisfies the generalized Hooke’s law in the elastic range, and has good linear behavior. In the premise that some nonlinear conditions like friction and lubrication are ignored, a linear model is used to describe the time-varying path of gear stress. The expression is defined as follows (2)fs(t)=μs(t)=a0+a1t
where a0 and a1 are the parameters to be estimated. They are affected by the variable wind speed and the external working conditions.

There are mainly two ways to solve the stress–strength interference model. The first is analytical method, but this method requires the performance function of structure (the functional relation which the structure needs to meet for the purpose of satisfying the reliability). In most cases, the performance functions are hard to obtain owing to the complex load and too many random variables, so it is limited in many cases. The other method to solve this problem is the simulation method which is based on the law of large numbers. A certain amount of stress values and strength values are sampled within the interference area and then compared separately. It can be proved that the accuracy can be guaranteed if number of the sampling achieves to 104 times. In addition, the simulation method is unaffected by the distribution form and the numbers of random variables, so it is an accurate and effective method to solve the stress–strength interference model.29 The main process of the simulation method is listed as follows:
Determine the probability distribution of gear stress.
Determine time-varying path of the deteriorated gear stress s(t).
Determine the probability distribution of gear strength.
Determine time-varying path of the degenerated strength S(t).
Solving the stress-strength interference model by Monte Carlo sampling at any moment ti.
Repeat the above processes and then fit these reliability values Ri into the dynamic reliability curve.

The processes above can be easily carried out when the gear data are sufficient, but due to the variable wind speed and the shortage of failure data, both the distribution parameters and the time-varying path are difficult to define. These will cause difficulties in establishing the stress–strength interference model. Next, both the two issues affected the solving of dynamic reliability for wind gears will be discussed.

sec.title: Stress distribution and mean stress path under the condition of variable wind speed
Probability characteristics of wind speed spectrum
sec.p:
The wind speed is unstable and has significant geographical feature. Commonly, probability of wind speed obeys the Weibull distribution or normal distribution, here the normal distribution N(μv, σv2) is used. If the wind data are acquired, they can be easily processed into the frequency histogram as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Frequency histogram of wind speed.

Since the probability can be approximated by the frequency, the mean (mathematical expectation) and the variance of the wind speed data can be calculated according to the frequency histogram. (3){μv=∑i=1 nvi piσv 2=E [v-E(v)]2
The disturbance of wind speed (σv2) will pass from the blades to the main drive shaft and subsequently to the gear stress.

sec.title: Stress distribution and time-varying path
sec.p: The wind energy transmitting to the driving gear is a complicated process. It is affected by the parameters of the blades and wind speed. According to the stress formula of loaded gear which is defined by the standard ISO-6336, taking gear contact stress for example, if other parameters are given, the gear stress s is proportional to T1/2. That is s = KHT1/2, where KH is the result which is calculated according to the standard ISO6336 except the torque T, and the variance of s can be deduced by the algorithm of multidimensional random variable. (4)D(s)=D(T 1/2)=KH 2σT 24μT 2

In addition, the torque T is related to the normal force of blade FBn. The expression is as follows (5)T=λlFBn where λ is the number of blades, l is the length of blade, and FBn can be calculated as follows30 (6)FBn=12ρ0CnS0v2
where ρ0 is the air density (kg/m3), S0 is the rotor swept area (m2), v is the wind speed (m/s) and Cn is the normal aerodynamic coefficient of the chord line. The expression is (7)Cn=Clcosi+Cdsini

where i is the attack angle of the blade; Cl and Cd represent the lift coefficient and the drag coefficient, respectively. Equations (5) to (7) indicate that when the blade parameters are given, the torque T is proportional to (v2): T = Kvv2 and Kv = (0.5λlρ0CnS0). The relationship between their digital characteristic is (8){E(T )=E(v2)=Kvμv 2D(T )=D(v2)=4Kv 2μv 2σv 2
Combining equation (4) with equation (8), relationship of variance between gear stress s and wind speed v is: (9)D(s)=(KHμv)2σv 2

Equation (9) indicates that the fluctuation of gear stress is amplified by (KH/μv)2 times when wind blow through the blade. At the same time, the gear stress will increase slowly with the passing of time and worse operating environment. In order to ensure the “deteriorating trend” of the gear stress, the parameters like KA, KV, KHα and ZH increase slowly as linear. Since the magnitudes of these parameters are the same, a uniform k0 is defined as a common linear growth rate to ensure this trend. When all these conditions are ready, the mean gear stress can be calculated any time. And the parameters a0 and a1 in equation (2) can be solved by these data.
Therefore, distribution and time-varying path of gear stress in Figure 1 can be determined in the condition of variable wind speed.

sec.title: Strength distribution and mean strength path under the condition of small samples
sec.p: In the dynamic stress–strength interference model, it not only needs to acquire the distribution and time-varying path of the gear stress, but also needs to acquire the distribution and time-varying path of the gear strength. According to the fatigue cumulative damage theory, it is easy to know that the gear strength will degenerate with elapsing time, but the time-varying path is difficult to predict owing to the lack of gear data. In order to solve this problem, a data conversion model is established. Strength data of gear transmission structures are selected from the gear experiment and transformed into equivalent data by the grey relational analysis. Then the parameter in equation (1) can be estimated by the Bayes method.

Essence of the data conversion model is to establish the criterion for gear data transformation. Relationship between the source data and the measured data is complicated once the design parameters are altered. So, the discussion will be carried out for this case. At the same time, it is important to declare that not all gear data are fit for data conversion due to their significant inconsistencies. The inherent premises are:
Gear types must be identical (for instance, data conversion cannot be carried out between bevel gear and circular gear).
The failure modes and failure mechanisms of gears must be identical (for instance, data conversion cannot be carried out between steel gear and plastic gear).
Magnitude of gear parameters must be in the same level (to avoid high nonlinear data conversion).

sec.title: Data conversion model
sec.p: Assuming that few experimental strength data of gear with similar structure to the object of study is obtained: S = [S1, S2 , …, Sm], m ≤ 8. The number of stress cycle is N = [N1, N2 , …, Nm], and N can be converted into the service time t(kh) (10)N=6×104tn

where n is the rotating speed of gear. For any strength data of gear Si (i = 1, 2 , …, m), its design parameters is x(i) = [xi1, xi2 , …, xin]. Meanwhile, if design parameters of the study object is x(0) = [x01, x02 , …, x0n], order that Δij = |x0j − xij|, j = 1, 2 , …, n, and then construct the following operators (11){Δmin=minj=1 n|Δij|Δmax=maxj=1 n|Δij|

where min|Δij|, max|Δij| represent the minimum and the maximum absolute difference. The correlation coefficient of the corresponding elements between x(i) and x(0) is expressed as (12)ɛj=Δmin+ρΔmaxΔij+ρΔmax
where ρ is the resolution ratio and 0 < ρ < 1. Generally, ρ is defined as 0.5. Taking the average value as the conversion coefficient of gear strength αi (13)αi=1n∑j=1 nɛ(i)j

Considering that each parameter has an inconsistent influence on the gear strength, and based on the precondition that other parameters would be unchanged, a same increment Δx is assigned to each element of x(0) and x(i) separately. The corresponding variety in gear strength can be calculated according to the standard ISO-6336: ΔS0 = [ΔS01, ΔS02 , … , ΔS0n] and ΔSi = [ΔSi1, ΔSi2 , … , ΔSin], then construct the following equation (14)ri=1n∑j=1 n(ΔSijΔS0j)
(15)And order that:wi=rin∑j=1 n(ΔS0j)
In this case, a data conversion model is established to transform the gear strength Si from the historical data (16)Si '=αiSi+wi
where αi is the conversion coefficient and wi is the model correction. Similarly, this data conversion model is available for other groups of gear data.

sec.title: Prediction of degenerated strength path by Bayse thought
sec.p: Since the material of gear is known, the shape parameter β1 in equation (1) is considered as constant. Then, the stress degradation rate β0 is defined as a random variable and its prior distribution is considered to satisfy the normal distribution N(μ0, σ02). The fatigue ultimate strength σlim can be acquired by referring to the S–N curve of gear material. On this basis, samples of gear strength S = [S10, S20 , … , Sm0] are calculated in combination with σlim and other parameters are provided by standard ISO-6336. These values are substituted into equation (1) separately, and the prior samples of the parameter β0 are acquired as: X = [X10, X20 , … , Xm0]. So, prior distribution parameters (μ0 and σ20) of the parameter β0 can be estimated by these prior samples.
In order to carry out Bayes data fusion, it is necessary to define the likelihood function (conditional density function) of β0 as (17)L(μ,σ2)=1(2πσ)ne-12σ2∑i=1 m(xi-μ)2

The equivalent values of gear strength S′ = [S′1, S′2 , … , S′m] are obtained by the data conversion model mentioned above. Similarly, these values are substituted into equation (1) and series samples of β0 are calculated: X′ = [X′1, X′2 , … , X′m]. These samples are considered as the field observations and used to estimate the distributed parameters (μ1 and σ21) of likelihood function. On this basis, Bayes data fusion is carried out. The expression is presented as follows (18)f (θ|x )=f (x|θ ) f (θ)∫Θf (x|θ ) f (θ)dθ

where f(θ) is the prior distribution of β0; f(x|θ) is the likelihood function of β0; f(θ|x) is the posterior distribution of β0. The posterior distribution of β0 contains both the information of the prior sample S = [S10, S20 , … , Sm0] (included in f(θ)) and the information of the observed data S = [S1, S2 ,… , Sm] (included in f(x|θ)). Owing to the conjugate character of normal distribution, it is easy to know that the f(θ|x) still obeys the normal distribution too. By solving the mathematical expectation of f(θ|x) in equation (18), the estimated value of β0 is (19)β∧0=E [θ|x ]=(σ0 2σ0 2+σ1 2)μ1+(σ1 2σ0 2+σ1 2)μ0
After estimating value of β0, it is actually determined the time-varying path of the residual strength. Hence, it's ready for the dynamic stress–strength interference model.

To sum up, on the condition of variable wind speed and small samples, the probability distribution and time-varying path for both gear stress and gear strength are determined. So, the stress–strength interference model and the Monte Carlo sampling are used to calculate the dynamic reliability of gear, and a dynamic curve for gears in a wind turbine gearbox can be finally obtained.

sec.p:

sec.title: Simulation analysis and results
sec.p:
On defining the probability distribution and time-varying path for both the gear stress and the gear strength, the Monte Carlo sampling is carried out to solve the static reliability in each times. In addition, the dynamic reliability curve is fitted by these static reliability values. This curve describes the evolution process of the reliability of the ring gear during its whole lifetime. The simulation of Monte Carlo sampling can be carried out in MATLAB 7.0,31 and the major steps are listed as follows:
To determine the probability distribution and the time-varying path of the gear stress and the gear strength using the probability density function (the normpdf function) and the cumulative distribution function (the normcdf function).
To generate a random number which ranges between 0 and 1 (the rand function).
To sample the stress si and the strength Si separately by the random number at the time ti. The numbers of each sampling are 104 times. Then the static strength reliability of the ring gear R(ti) satisfies the statistical result which is derived from equation (20).
To repeat the above steps following the time increment until the simulations of all samplings are completed.
To fit the dynamic reliability curve of this ring gear on the basis of these discrete data.
(20) R(ti)=N[(si-Si)<0]NT

In equation (20), si is the gear stress of the ith sampling; Si is the gear strength of the ith sampling; N[(si − Si) < 0] is the statistics number of the sampling where the gear stress is smaller than the gear strength; NT is the total number of sampling. The dynamic reliability curve of the ring gear after calculation is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Dynamic reliability curve of the ring gear.

Result shown in Figure 3 indicates that the method of this study can predict the dynamic reliability of gear in a wind turbine gearbox under the conditions of variable wind speed and small samples. Curve of the dynamic failure rate is generally called the bathtub curve. It has all characteristics of the bathtub curve: the infant mortality period, the random failure period and the wear out period. Owing to the “deteriorating effect” of gear stress and the “degradation effect” of gear strength, the reliability of the ring gear decreases faster than its expectations: when t = 17.5 kh (used for about 2 years), the reliability is 98% approximately; Meanwhile, when t = 35 kh (used for about 4 years), the reliability is only 89% approximately. It well explains the phenomenon of gear fatigue.

Besides, it can be inferred that the reliability of this ring gear decreases faster in the period of 50 kh (about 5.7 years) to 80 kh (about 9 years). It means that this ring gear has a higher failure probability in this period.

In addition, a series of numerical experiments are carried out for analyzing as to how the fluctuation of wind speed will affect the reliability of ring gear. It is supposed that other conditions are constant and only the variance of wind speed varies within a certain range, and the stress distribution of the ring gear changes accordingly. Reliability of the ring gear is recalculated when the variance of wind speed values at σv2 = 35, σv2 = 45 and σv2 = 55 separately; furthermore, the simulations are separately carried out when t = 35 kh, t = 40 kh and t = 45 kh. The results are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Influences on reliability by wind speed fluctuations.

Figure 4 shows that reliability of the ring gear decreases when the variance of wind speed becomes larger. In other words, the fluctuation characteristics of wind speed will lead to a lower reliability than its expectation. Besides, by comparing the slope of the three curves, it can be found that the reliability is more sensitive in the infant mortality period, and it declines faster during this period.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This article concentrated on the dynamic reliability of gears in a wind turbine gearbox, with the consideration of the influence of the variable wind speed and the small samples. The deteriorating effect of gear stress is considered with the time elapse. Also, the strength distribution and its time-varying path are determined with the combination of the data conversion model and the Bayes data fusion. Then, the dynamic reliability of a ring gear is calculated based on the stress–strength interference model and Monte Carlo sampling. Here are some main conclusions of this article.
The probability distribution of gear stress is influenced by the fluctuation of wind speed. In this case, the stress fluctuation is magnified by (KH/μv)2 times and the gear reliability is lower than its expectation. Meanwhile, this fluctuation of wind speed has more remarkable impact on reliability in the period of infant mortality.
To overcome the limitation that the gear reliability cannot be solved due to the shortage of failure samples. The grey relational analysis guarantees the equivalent transformation of the gear strength data, and, the Bayes data fusion realizes the combination of prior and historical information. On these bases, the strength degradation path has more practical meaning.
The effectiveness of data fusion mainly depends on two factors: the similarity of the structure between the selected samples and the object of study; the validity of the fusion algorithm. Data fusion model of this work can ensure a more effective conversion even when the structure is not exactly equal.
Due to the “deteriorating effect” of the stress and the “degradation effect” of the strength, values of the stress and the strength moves oppositely. This phenomenon accelerated the gear fatigue.
Result of the example shows that the dynamic reliability of gears in a wind turbine gearbox can be effectively predicted under the conditions of variable wind speed and small samples; the dynamic reliability curve of the ring gear has all characteristics of the bathtub curve. It provides a reasonable way to predict the dynamic reliability of gears in a wind turbine gearbox.
